elements.content: Presented here are two serine-based homochiral materials that show isostructural nanoporous three-dimensional frameworks with high selectivity and storage capacity for CO2 over N2 and CO at ambient conditions.
elements.clean_text: Presented here are two serine-based homochiral materials that show isostructural nanoporous three-dimensional frameworks with high selectivity and storage capacity for CO2 over N2 and CO at ambient conditions.

elements.content: Presented here are two serine-based homochiral materials which show isostructural nanoporous three-dimensional frameworks with high selectivity and storage capacity for CO2 over N2 and CO at ambient conditions.
elements.clean_text: Presented here are two serine-based homochiral materials which show isostructural nanoporous three-dimensional frameworks with high selectivity and storage capacity for CO2 over N2 and CO at ambient conditions.

elements.content: The reduction of CO2 in the air is now a worldwide task to avoid the greenhouse effect. Selective trapping of CO2 from air or the emissions of coal-fired power plants under ambient conditions becomes more and more important for this purpose. Recently, porous metal organic framework materials (MOFs) have been considered as very promising candidate for gas storage and separation because of their high surface area and tunable structural features. The storage of CO2 and its selective separation from gas mixtures are two main tasks for MOF materials. Of particular interest is the efficient separation of CO2 from N2 at ambient temperature and pressure, because that is the key fact in the capture of carbon from flue gas. Numbers of MOF materials with selective adsorption of CO2 over N2 have been reported in near five years, but highly efficient materials are still rare emerging. So far how to enhance the separation ability of the materials from structural modification approach remains great challenge. The current research efforts in this area have focused on either (1) increasing pore volume or surface area to improve CO2 capacity or (2) modifying the physical and chemical environments in pores by introducing functional moieties with high affinity to CO2. It has been recognized that some specific polar groups, for example, −OH, −COOH, or −NH2, can dramatically help on the selectivity of CO2 rather than other gases (e.g., N2, CH4, H2). Considering the above points, what should happen if a combination of such specific polar groups in a molecular building block was realized by the porous MOF material? Unfortunately, the answer is still unknown and no related porous MOF materials are synthesized.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The reduction of CO2 in the air is now a worldwide task to avoid the greenhouse effect. Selective trapping of CO2 from air or the emissions of coal-fired power plants under ambient conditions becomes more and more important for this purpose. Recently, porous metal organic framework materials (MOFs) have been considered as very promising candidate for gas storage and separation because of their high surface area and tunable structural features. The storage of CO2 and its selective separation from gas mixtures are two main tasks for MOF materials. Of particular interest is the efficient separation of CO2 from N2 at ambient temperature and pressure, because that is the key fact in the capture of carbon from flue gas. Numbers of MOF materials with selective adsorption of CO2 over N2 have been reported in near five years, but highly efficient materials are still rare emerging. So far how to enhance the separation ability of the materials from structural modification approach remains great challenge. The current research efforts in this area have focused on either (1) increasing pore volume or surface area to improve CO2 capacity or (2) modifying the physical and chemical environments in pores by introducing functional moieties with high affinity to CO2. It has been recognized that some specific polar groups, for example, -OH, -COOH, or -NH2, can dramatically help on the selectivity of CO2 rather than other gases (e.g., N2, CH4, H2). Considering the above points, what should happen if a combination of such specific polar groups in a molecular building block was realized by the porous MOF material? Unfortunately, the answer is still unknown and no related porous MOF materials are synthesized.

elements.content: A special molecule containing all −OH, −COOH, and −NH2 groups is serine, one of the typical amino acid. However, porous three-dimensional MOF materials based on serine have never been explored to date, although other amino acid-based porous MOFs have been reported. Serine is such a functional ligand not only due to its multidentate coordinate sites, but also due to its intrinsic homochirality. MOFs constructed from commercial available enantiopure serine should take another outstanding merit on homochiral applications, such as enantioselective catalysis and separation. Since the presence of rich polar groups, serine-based porous MOF materials may open a new approach toward the CO2 capture and its selective separation.
elements.clean_text: A special molecule containing all -OH, -COOH, and -NH2 groups is serine, one of the typical amino acid. However, porous three-dimensional MOF materials based on serine have never been explored to date, although other amino acid-based porous MOFs have been reported. Serine is such a functional ligand not only due to its multidentate coordinate sites, but also due to its intrinsic homochirality. MOFs constructed from commercial available enantiopure serine should take another outstanding merit on homochiral applications, such as enantioselective catalysis and separation. Since the presence of rich polar groups, serine-based porous MOF materials may open a new approach toward the CO2 capture and its selective separation.

elements.content: Herein, we report two homochiral materials synthesized from d- or l-serine, respectively, which show isostructural nanoporous three-dimensional frameworks with high selectivity and storage capacity for carbon dioxide over nitrogen at ambient conditions.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we report two homochiral materials synthesized from d- or l-serine, respectively, which show isostructural nanoporous three-dimensional frameworks with high selectivity and storage capacity for carbon dioxide over nitrogen at ambient conditions.

elements.content: All the syntheses were performed in 20 mL glass vial under autogenous pressure. Reagents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. Thermal analysis was carried out on a Netzsch STA449C thermal analyzer under dinitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C·min–1. X-ray powder diffraction experiments were performed in a Rigaku Dmax 2500 instrument with an ultra 18Kw Cu rotating anode point source. Gas adsorption measurement was performed in the ASAP (Accelerated Surface Area and Porosimetry) 2020 System.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Procedures

All the syntheses were performed in 20 mL glass vial under autogenous pressure. Reagents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. Thermal analysis was carried out on a Netzsch STA449C thermal analyzer under dinitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C⋅min-1. X-ray powder diffraction experiments were performed in a Rigaku Dmax 2500 instrument with an ultra 18Kw Cu rotating anode point source. Gas adsorption measurement was performed in the ASAP (Accelerated Surface Area and Porosimetry) 2020 System.

elements.content: A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.595 g, 2 mmol), L-serine (l-Ser, 0.105 g, 1 mmol), terephthalic acid (H2bdc, 0.166 g, 1 mmol), and 10 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) was heated up and stirred to give a yellow clear solution, and then transferred and sealed in a 23 mL of Teflon-lined airtight reactor was heated at 120 °C for 2 days, and then cooled to room-temperature. Fresh DMF was used to wash the primrose yellow crystals, and the obtained crystals were stored in a desiccator.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Zn4(l-Ser)2(bdc)⋅6DMF (1-L)

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.595 g, 2 mmol), L-serine (l-Ser, 0.105 g, 1 mmol), terephthalic acid (H2bdc, 0.166 g, 1 mmol), and 10 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) was heated up and stirred to give a yellow clear solution, and then transferred and sealed in a 23 mL of Teflon-lined airtight reactor was heated at 120 °C for 2 days, and then cooled to room-temperature. Fresh DMF was used to wash the primrose yellow crystals, and the obtained crystals were stored in a desiccator.

elements.content:
1-D was prepared by a procedure similar with that of 1-L, except for the replacement of l-serine by d-serine.

X-ray Crystallography

The diffraction data was collected on a Saturn 70 charge-coupled device diffractometer equipped with confocal-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. The CrystalClear program was used for absorption correction. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix, least-squares methods using the SHELXL-97 program package. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The total interstitial solvent molecule contents of 1 were determined by TGA. Crystal data for 1-L and 1-D are listed in Table .
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Zn4(d-Ser)2(bdc)⋅6DMF (1-D)

 1-D was prepared by a procedure similar with that of 1-L, except for the replacement of l-serine by d-serine.

X-ray Crystallography

The diffraction data was collected on a Saturn 70 charge-coupled device diffractometer equipped with confocal-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. The CrystalClear program was used for absorption correction. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix, least-squares methods using the SHELXL-97 program package. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The total interstitial solvent molecule contents of 1 were determined by TGA. Crystal data for 1-L and 1-D are listed in Table .

Compounds were synthesized, respectively, by mixing serine (d- or l-form), 1,4-benzenebicarboxlic acid (H2bdc), and Zn(NO3)2·6H2O in a 1:1:2 molar ratio in DMF solution at 120 °C for 2 days. Single-crystal X-ray Diffraction studies reveal that they are isostructural and formulated as [Zn4(bdc)2(l-ser)2)]·6DMF (1-L) and [Zn4(bdc)2(d-Ser)2)]·6DMF (1-D), respectively. The phase purity of the bulk product was independently confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Compounds were synthesized, respectively, by mixing serine (d- or l-form), 1,4-benzenebicarboxlic acid (H2bdc), and Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O in a 1:1:2 molar ratio in DMF solution at 120 °C for 2 days. Single-crystal X-ray Diffraction studies reveal that they are isostructural and formulated as [Zn4(bdc)2(l-ser)2)]⋅6DMF (1-L) and [Zn4(bdc)2(d-Ser)2)]⋅6DMF (1-D), respectively. The phase purity of the bulk product was independently confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD).

elements.content: The prominent structural feature of 1-L is that the homochiral chains built from enantiopure l-serine and Zn centers are linked together by achiral bdc ligands to form a rod-and-spacer motif with large rhombic channels. Compound 1-L crystallized in the chiral P21 space group because of the derivation from the enantiopure l-serine. It is notable that the coordination fashion of l-serine in the structure is unprecedented, because it is a dianion owing to the deprotonation of the hydroxy group and acts as an unusual μ4-ligand to bound four Zn2+ ions (Figure a). The interesting point is that the −NH2 group of l-serine bridges two Zn centers with the Zn···Zn distance being 3.52 Å. Each five-coordinate Zn center (ZnO4N) has distorted trigonal bipyramid geometry, and they are connected by the l-serine ligands into a homochiral chain along the c axis (Figure a). Meanwhile, the achiral bdc ligands, whose oxygen atoms occupy the equatorial positions of the homochiral chains, further bridge these parallel homochiral chains to form a neutral 3D framework with large channels along the c axis (Figure b). The effective size of this rhombic window for each channel is about 20 × 10 Å2 by measuring the diagonal centers. A large void is generated within the channels with the Vvoid without guest DMF molecules of 63.3% as calculated by PLATON. The channels are occupied by the structural disordered DMF molecules. There are six DMF guest molecules per formula unit of the host, as evidenced by thermal gravimetric (TG) analysis data. Compound 1-D prepared from d-serine is the enantiomorphism of 1-L and has similar homochiral structure (space group: P21) to 1-L. The framework structure of 1-L is also similar to the reported compound [Zn2(bdc)(l-lactate)(DMF)]·DMF where the l-lactate ligand was used and each Zn center is coordinated by one solvent DMF molecule. In 1-L, the −OH group of l-serine acted as a tailor and replaced the coordination site of DMF in that reported compound. Thus it becomes much easier for 1-L to remove the solvent DMF molecules from the pores.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Sructure Description

The prominent structural feature of 1-L is that the homochiral chains built from enantiopure l-serine and Zn centers are linked together by achiral bdc ligands to form a rod-and-spacer motif with large rhombic channels. Compound 1-L crystallized in the chiral P21 space group because of the derivation from the enantiopure l-serine. It is notable that the coordination fashion of l-serine in the structure is unprecedented, because it is a dianion owing to the deprotonation of the hydroxy group and acts as an unusual μ4-ligand to bound four Zn2+ ions (Figure a). The interesting point is that the -NH2 group of l-serine bridges two Zn centers with the Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distance being 3.52 Å. Each five-coordinate Zn center (ZnO4N) has distorted trigonal bipyramid geometry, and they are connected by the l-serine ligands into a homochiral chain along the c axis (Figure a). Meanwhile, the achiral bdc ligands, whose oxygen atoms occupy the equatorial positions of the homochiral chains, further bridge these parallel homochiral chains to form a neutral 3D framework with large channels along the c axis (Figure b). The effective size of this rhombic window for each channel is about 20 × 10 Å2 by measuring the diagonal centers. A large void is generated within the channels with the Vvoid without guest DMF molecules of 63.3% as calculated by PLATON. The channels are occupied by the structural disordered DMF molecules. There are six DMF guest molecules per formula unit of the host, as evidenced by thermal gravimetric (TG) analysis data. Compound 1-D prepared from d-serine is the enantiomorphism of 1-L and has similar homochiral structure (space group: P21) to 1-L. The framework structure of 1-L is also similar to the reported compound [Zn2(bdc)(l-lactate)(DMF)]⋅DMF where the l-lactate ligand was used and each Zn center is coordinated by one solvent DMF molecule. In 1-L, the -OH group of l-serine acted as a tailor and replaced the coordination site of DMF in that reported compound. Thus it becomes much easier for 1-L to remove the solvent DMF molecules from the pores.

elements.content: (a) Coordination environment of Zn atom in 1-L. (b) The 3D porous framework viewed along the c axis.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Coordination environment of Zn atom in 1-L. (b) The 3D porous framework viewed along the c axis.

elements.content: Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) and X-ray powder diffraction pattern (XRPD) measurements were carried out to examine the thermal stability of this nanoporous framework. The TGA curve of 1-L shows that the trapped solvent DMF molecules can be drastically removed at 250 °C with a weight loss of 35.4% (calculated 35.6%) ( Figure S2a). The hollow phase (1-L-ht) of 1-L was obtained after heated at 180 °C for 7 h under high vacuum (10–8 mbar), the powder X-ray diffraction pattern of 1-L-ht have appeared obvious change ( Figure S3c). It may be due to the laxity of 1-L after the removal of DMF guests. To attain a more complete evacuation and protect the structural integrality, DMF was exchanged with methanol by soaking crystals of 1-L in methanol for one week. As indicated by TGA and infrared spectroscopy, the methanol activated material 1′-L is DMF free ( Figures S2b and S4). Its TGA curve showed that methanol was released below 100 °C. Its hollow phase (1′-L-ht) was obtained after heated at 80 °C for 7 h under high vacuum.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Stability

Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) and X-ray powder diffraction pattern (XRPD) measurements were carried out to examine the thermal stability of this nanoporous framework. The TGA curve of 1-L shows that the trapped solvent DMF molecules can be drastically removed at 250 °C with a weight loss of 35.4% (calculated 35.6%) ( Figure S2a). The hollow phase (1-L-ht) of 1-L was obtained after heated at 180 °C for 7 h under high vacuum (10-8 mbar), the powder X-ray diffraction pattern of 1-L-ht have appeared obvious change ( Figure S3c). It may be due to the laxity of 1-L after the removal of DMF guests. To attain a more complete evacuation and protect the structural integrality, DMF was exchanged with methanol by soaking crystals of 1-L in methanol for one week. As indicated by TGA and infrared spectroscopy, the methanol activated material 1'-L is DMF free ( Figures S2b and S4). Its TGA curve showed that methanol was released below 100 °C. Its hollow phase (1'-L-ht) was obtained after heated at 80 °C for 7 h under high vacuum.

elements.content: The permanent porosity of 1-L-ht was established by reversible gas sorption experiments using N2 and CO2 at 77 and 195 K, respectively, which all show a typical type I behavior characterized by a plateau reached at low relative pressure indicating the presence of permanent micropores in 1-L-ht (Figure and Table ). The lower uptake of N2 (42 cm3/g) and higher uptake of CO2 (127 cm3/g) may be induced by the strong polar environment in the pores. N2 adsorption data gives a BET surface area of 136.9 m2/g and a Langmuir surface area of 180.4 m2/g. A single data point at relative pressure 0.295 gives a maxima pore volume of 0.063 cm3/g by the Horvath–Kawazoe equation. Comparatively, the maximum N2 uptakes at 1 bar for 1′-L-ht are 92.3 cm3/g (STP), giving a BET surface area of 224.7 m2/g and a Langmuir surface area of 298.5 m2/g, which are all much larger than that for 1-L-ht. A single data point at relative pressure 0.01 gives a maxima pore volume of 0.081 cm3/g by the Horvath–Kawazoe equation. The results demonstrate the importance of activation for porous materials.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Sorption Properties

The permanent porosity of 1-L-ht was established by reversible gas sorption experiments using N2 and CO2 at 77 and 195 K, respectively, which all show a typical type I behavior characterized by a plateau reached at low relative pressure indicating the presence of permanent micropores in 1-L-ht (Figure  and Table ). The lower uptake of N2 (42 cm3/g) and higher uptake of CO2 (127 cm3/g) may be induced by the strong polar environment in the pores. N2 adsorption data gives a BET surface area of 136.9 m2/g and a Langmuir surface area of 180.4 m2/g. A single data point at relative pressure 0.295 gives a maxima pore volume of 0.063 cm3/g by the Horvath-Kawazoe equation. Comparatively, the maximum N2 uptakes at 1 bar for 1'-L-ht are 92.3 cm3/g (STP), giving a BET surface area of 224.7 m2/g and a Langmuir surface area of 298.5 m2/g, which are all much larger than that for 1-L-ht. A single data point at relative pressure 0.01 gives a maxima pore volume of 0.081 cm3/g by the Horvath-Kawazoe equation. The results demonstrate the importance of activation for porous materials.

elements.content: N2 and CO2 adsorption isotherms: (a) N2 at 77 K for 1-L-ht, (b) N2 at 77 K for 1′-L-ht, (c) CO2 at 195 K for 1-L-ht, and (d) the hysteresis loop of CO2 at 195 K for 1-L-ht.
elements.clean_text: 2  N2 and CO2 adsorption isotherms: (a) N2 at 77 K for 1-L-ht, (b) N2 at 77 K for 1'-L-ht, (c) CO2 at 195 K for 1-L-ht, and (d) the hysteresis loop of CO2 at 195 K for 1-L-ht.

elements.content:
Adsorption Data and Isosteric Heat Data for <bold>1-L-ht</bold> and <bold>1́-L-ht</bold> compound BET CO2@273 K CO2@298 K Qst(CO2) S(CO2/N2)@273 K H2@77 K H2@87 K Qst(H2) 1-L-ht 136.9 55.5 37.1 32.1 185 105.8 79.8 8.2 1′-L-ht 224.7 43.7 30.3 28.6 17.5 66.7 50.7 7.5

Surface area, m2/g.

Adsorptive capability, mL/g.

Isosteric heat of adsorption at 1 bar, kJ/mol.

Selectivity of CO2 over N2, v/v.

It is worth noting that there is a small hysteresis loop for the CO2 sorption of 1-L-ht, suggesting relatively strong adsorbent–adsorbate interactions between the framework and CO2. This phenomenon encourages us to further explore its potential properties on CO2/N2 gas separation under ambient conditions. The adsorption isotherms of CO2 and N2 for 1-L-ht and 1′-L-ht at 273 K were measured, respectively (Figure , Table ). The uptake value of CO2 for 1-L-ht was 55.5 cm3/g (2.49 mmol/g and 109.2 mg/g), which is comparable to the well-known MOF-5 and larger than many other reported compounds. However, the CO2 uptake of 43.7 cm3/g for 1′-L-ht is much less than that of 1-L-ht. In particular, CO2 uptake (42.1 mg/g at 273 K) of 1-L-ht at 0.1 bar, a typical partial pressure of CO2 in flue gases from power plants and steel mills, is comparable or even superior to that of many MOFs. To better understand these observations, the adsorptive capability of 1-L-ht and 1′-L-ht were measured under 298 K, giving an uptake of 37.1 cm3/g for 1-L-ht and 21.4 cm3/g for 1′-L-ht (Figure b and d). The enthalpy of CO2 adsorption for 1-L-ht was estimated from the sorption isotherms at 273 and 298 K using the virial equation to understand the strong affinity of 1-L-ht toward CO2 ( Figures S5 and S6). At zero coverage, the enthalpy of CO2 adsorption is 32.1 kJ/mol for 1-L-ht and 28.6 kJ/mol for 1′-L-ht, which is comparable to those of MOFs with organic ammonium ions in the pores for strong CO2 binding. In contrast, N2 was hardly adsorbed at all under the conditions of 273 K (just 0.3 cm3/g for 1-L-ht and 2.5 cm3/g for 1′-L-ht). The maximal uptakes of the CO2 and N2 at 273 K and 1 bar for 1-L-ht were used to estimate the adsorption selectivity for CO2 over N2. From these data, the calculated CO2/N2 selectivity is 185:1 for 1-L-ht and 17.5:1 for 1′-L-ht at 273 K. MOFs with such high CO2/N2 adsorption selectivity at ambient conditions were rarely reported.
elements.clean_text: It is worth noting that there is a small hysteresis loop for the CO2 sorption of 1-L-ht, suggesting relatively strong adsorbent-adsorbate interactions between the framework and CO2. This phenomenon encourages us to further explore its potential properties on CO2/N2 gas separation under ambient conditions. The adsorption isotherms of CO2 and N2 for 1-L-ht and 1'-L-ht at 273 K were measured, respectively (Figure , Table ). The uptake value of CO2 for 1-L-ht was 55.5 cm3/g (2.49 mmol/g and 109.2 mg/g), which is comparable to the well-known MOF-5 and larger than many other reported compounds. However, the CO2 uptake of 43.7 cm3/g for 1'-L-ht is much less than that of 1-L-ht. In particular, CO2 uptake (42.1 mg/g at 273 K) of 1-L-ht at 0.1 bar, a typical partial pressure of CO2 in flue gases from power plants and steel mills, is comparable or even superior to that of many MOFs. To better understand these observations, the adsorptive capability of 1-L-ht and 1'-L-ht were measured under 298 K, giving an uptake of 37.1 cm3/g for 1-L-ht and 21.4 cm3/g for 1'-L-ht (Figure b and d). The enthalpy of CO2 adsorption for 1-L-ht was estimated from the sorption isotherms at 273 and 298 K using the virial equation to understand the strong affinity of 1-L-ht toward CO2 ( Figures S5 and S6). At zero coverage, the enthalpy of CO2 adsorption is 32.1 kJ/mol for 1-L-ht and 28.6 kJ/mol for 1'-L-ht, which is comparable to those of MOFs with organic ammonium ions in the pores for strong CO2 binding. In contrast, N2 was hardly adsorbed at all under the conditions of 273 K (just 0.3 cm3/g for 1-L-ht and 2.5 cm3/g for 1'-L-ht). The maximal uptakes of the CO2 and N2 at 273 K and 1 bar for 1-L-ht were used to estimate the adsorption selectivity for CO2 over N2. From these data, the calculated CO2/N2 selectivity is 185:1 for 1-L-ht and 17.5:1 for 1'-L-ht at 273 K. MOFs with such high CO2/N2 adsorption selectivity at ambient conditions were rarely reported.

elements.content: N2 and CO2 adsorption isotherms: (a) CO2 at 273 K for 1-L-ht, (b) CO2 at 298 K for 1-L-ht, (c) CO2 at 273 K for 1′-L-ht, (d) CO2 at 298 K for 1′-L-ht, (e) N2 at 273 K for 1-L-ht and (f) N2 at 273 K for 1′-L-ht.
elements.clean_text: 3  N2 and CO2 adsorption isotherms: (a) CO2 at 273 K for 1-L-ht, (b) CO2 at 298 K for 1-L-ht, (c) CO2 at 273 K for 1'-L-ht, (d) CO2 at 298 K for 1'-L-ht, (e) N2 at 273 K for 1-L-ht and (f) N2 at 273 K for 1'-L-ht.

elements.content: In view of the structural feature of 1-L, such gas-adsorption selectivity might be associated with the presence the π-electrons of the ligands and the polar −NH2 groups, giving rise to an electric field to induce a dipole in CO2 and an interaction between CO2 and −NH2. The presence of the μ2-NH2 groups and CO groups of neighboring ligands provides chances on the inteaction betwwen of CO2 and −NH2. These cooperative effects yield an enhanced lone pair polarization of the CO2 electron density, highlighting the impact of the specific pore geometry in the structure of 1-L.
elements.clean_text: In view of the structural feature of 1-L, such gas-adsorption selectivity might be associated with the presence the π-electrons of the ligands and the polar -NH2 groups, giving rise to an electric field to induce a dipole in CO2 and an interaction between CO2 and -NH2. The presence of the μ2-NH2 groups and CO groups of neighboring ligands provides chances on the inteaction betwwen of CO2 and -NH2. These cooperative effects yield an enhanced lone pair polarization of the CO2 electron density, highlighting the impact of the specific pore geometry in the structure of 1-L.

elements.content: The high-press sorption experiments of CO2 and CO were also measured at 298 K for 1-L-ht, which show distinct sorption behavior. The CO2 uptake by 1-L-ht at 40 bar can reach 84 cm3/g (3.75 mmol/g) and are not fully saturated, while the saturated uptake of CO is limited to 22 cm3/g (0.98 mmol/g) at 26 bar (Figure ). Interestingly, there is significant hysteresis for CO2 sorption whereas it is opposite for CO sorption. The significant hysteresis for 1-L-ht may be attributed to the dynamic feature of the host framework. The selective adsorption of CO2 over CO may be attributed to the sorbate–sorbent affinity between the CO2 molecules and the polar framework.

The CO2 uptake by 1-L-ht at 40 bar can reach 84 cm3/g (3.75 mmol/g) and are not fully saturated, while the saturated uptake of CO is limited to 22 cm3/g (0.98 mmol/g) at 26 bar (Figure ). Interestingly, there is significant hysteresis for CO2 sorption whereas it is opposite for CO sorption. The significant hysteresis for 1-L-ht may be attributed to the dynamic feature of the host framework. The selective adsorption of CO2 over CO may be attributed to the sorbate-sorbent affinity between the CO2 molecules and the polar framework.

elements.clean_text: 4  High-pressure adsorption isotherms of CO2 and CO at 298 K for 1-L-ht.

elements.content: Low-pressure H2 adsorption isotherms collected for samples of 1-L-ht and 1′-L-ht indicated that the framework had a strong affinity for binding H2 (Table and Figure ). At 77 K and 1.06 bar (800 Torr), a fully reversible uptake of 105.8 mL/g H2 for 1-L-ht but 66.7 cm3/g H2 for 1′-L-ht are apparent. As a further test, a second H2 adsorption isotherm was measured at 87 K, and the two data sets were used to determine the isosteric heat of H2 adsorption. The enthalpy of H2 adsorption for 1-L-ht and 1′-L-ht and was estimated from the sorption isotherms at 77 and 87 K using the virial equation to understand the affinity of 1-L-ht and 1′-L-ht toward H2 ( Figure S8–10). The isosteric heat of H2 adsorption for 1-L-ht and 1′-L-ht reach the values of 8.2 and 7.5 kJ/mol.
elements.clean_text: Low-pressure H2 adsorption isotherms collected for samples of 1-L-ht and 1'-L-ht indicated that the framework had a strong affinity for binding H2 (Table  and Figure ). At 77 K and 1.06 bar (800 Torr), a fully reversible uptake of 105.8 mL/g H2 for 1-L-ht but 66.7 cm3/g H2 for 1'-L-ht are apparent. As a further test, a second H2 adsorption isotherm was measured at 87 K, and the two data sets were used to determine the isosteric heat of H2 adsorption. The enthalpy of H2 adsorption for 1-L-ht and 1'-L-ht and was estimated from the sorption isotherms at 77 and 87 K using the virial equation to understand the affinity of 1-L-ht and 1'-L-ht toward H2 ( Figure S8-10). The isosteric heat of H2 adsorption for 1-L-ht and 1'-L-ht reach the values of 8.2 and 7.5 kJ/mol.

elements.content: What is more, the gravimetric H2 and CH4 sorption isotherms of 1-L-ht were also measured at 77 and 273 K, respectively. The H2 sorption on 1-L-ht showed type-I sorption behavior indicatives of the filling of the micropores only. The capacity of 1-L-ht to adsorb H2 increases to a saturation of 1.87 wt % at 32 bar (Figure ), and the adsorption amounts of CH4 is 5.64 wt % at 6 bar (Figure ). In addition, the density of the maximum adsorbed H2 (2.77 wt %, obtained by fitting of the Langmuir–Freundlich (L–F) equation to the adsorption isotherm.) is much higher than the experimental value (1.87 wt %).
elements.clean_text: What is more, the gravimetric H2 and CH4 sorption isotherms of 1-L-ht were also measured at 77 and 273 K, respectively. The H2 sorption on 1-L-ht showed type-I sorption behavior indicatives of the filling of the micropores only. The capacity of 1-L-ht to adsorb H2 increases to a saturation of 1.87 wt % at 32 bar (Figure ), and the adsorption amounts of CH4 is 5.64 wt % at 6 bar (Figure ). In addition, the density of the maximum adsorbed H2 (2.77 wt %, obtained by fitting of the Langmuir-Freundlich (L-F) equation to the adsorption isotherm.) is much higher than the experimental value (1.87 wt %).

elements.content: H2 adsorption isotherm for 1-L-ht recorded at 77 K, and the red solid line is the fitting of the H2 adsorption isotherm of 1-L-ht using Langmuir–Freundlich equation.

elements.content: In summary, two serine-based homochiral nanoporous framework materials were successfully synthesized and 1-L exhibited high selectivity and storage capacity for CO2 over N2 and CO at ambient conditions. The results indicated the special coordination mode of serine ligand and its functionality on CO2 uptake. This work also revealed that a flexible framework material with suitable pore size and polar functional groups may be a good candidate for the application in CO2/N2 separation.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, two serine-based homochiral nanoporous framework materials were successfully synthesized and 1-L exhibited high selectivity and storage capacity for CO2 over N2 and CO at ambient conditions. The results indicated the special coordination mode of serine ligand and its functionality on CO2 uptake. This work also revealed that a flexible framework material with suitable pore size and polar functional groups may be a good candidate for the application in CO2/N2 separation.

References

cln_elements.content: A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.595 g, 2 mmol), L-serine (l-Ser, 0.105 g, 1 mmol), terephthalic acid (H2bdc, 0.166 g, 1 mmol), and 10 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) was heated up and stirred to give a yellow clear solution, and then transferred and sealed in a 23 mL of Teflon-lined airtight reactor was heated at 120 °C for 2 days, and then cooled to room-temperature. Fresh DMF was used to wash the primrose yellow crystals, and the obtained crystals were stored in a desiccator.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Zn4(l-Ser)2(bdc)⋅6DMF (1-L)

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.595 g, 2 mmol), L-serine (l-Ser, 0.105 g, 1 mmol), terephthalic acid (H2bdc, 0.166 g, 1 mmol), and 10 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) was heated up and stirred to give a yellow clear solution, and then transferred and sealed in a 23 mL of Teflon-lined airtight reactor was heated at 120 °C for 2 days, and then cooled to room-temperature. Fresh DMF was used to wash the primrose yellow crystals, and the obtained crystals were stored in a desiccator.

cln_elements.content:
Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) and X-ray powder diffraction pattern (XRPD) measurements were carried out to examine the thermal stability of this nanoporous framework. The TGA curve of 1-L shows that the trapped solvent DMF molecules can be drastically removed at 250 °C with a weight loss of 35.4% (calculated 35.6%) ( Figure S2a). The hollow phase (1-L-ht) of 1-L was obtained after heated at 180 °C for 7 h under high vacuum (10–8 mbar), the powder X-ray diffraction pattern of 1-L-ht have appeared obvious change ( Figure S3c). It may be due to the laxity of 1-L after the removal of DMF guests. To attain a more complete evacuation and protect the structural integrality, DMF was exchanged with methanol by soaking crystals of 1-L in methanol for one week. As indicated by TGA and infrared spectroscopy, the methanol activated material 1′-L is DMF free ( Figures S2b and S4). Its TGA curve showed that methanol was released below 100 °C. Its hollow phase (1′-L-ht) was obtained after heated at 80 °C for 7 h under high vacuum.

Gas Sorption Properties

The permanent porosity of 1-L-ht was established by reversible gas sorption experiments using N2 and CO2 at 77 and 195 K, respectively, which all show a typical type I behavior characterized by a plateau reached at low relative pressure indicating the presence of permanent micropores in 1-L-ht (Figure and Table ). The lower uptake of N2 (42 cm3/g) and higher uptake of CO2 (127 cm3/g) may be induced by the strong polar environment in the pores. N2 adsorption data gives a BET surface area of 136.9 m2/g and a Langmuir surface area of 180.4 m2/g. A single data point at relative pressure 0.295 gives a maxima pore volume of 0.063 cm3/g by the Horvath–Kawazoe equation. Comparatively, the maximum N2 uptakes at 1 bar for 1′-L-ht are 92.3 cm3/g (STP), giving a BET surface area of 224.7 m2/g and a Langmuir surface area of 298.5 m2/g, which are all much larger than that for 1-L-ht. A single data point at relative pressure 0.01 gives a maxima pore volume of 0.081 cm3/g by the Horvath–Kawazoe equation. The results demonstrate the importance of activation for porous materials.

The high-press sorption experiments of CO2 and CO were also measured at 298 K for 1-L-ht, which show distinct sorption behavior. The CO2 uptake by 1-L-ht at 40 bar can reach 84 cm3/g (3.75 mmol/g) and are not fully saturated, while the saturated uptake of CO is limited to 22 cm3/g (0.98 mmol/g) at 26 bar (Figure ). Interestingly, there is significant hysteresis for CO2 sorption whereas it is opposite for CO sorption. The significant hysteresis for 1-L-ht may be attributed to the dynamic feature of the host framework. The selective adsorption of CO2 over CO may be attributed to the sorbate–sorbent affinity between the CO2 molecules and the polar framework.

Low-pressure H2 adsorption isotherms collected for samples of 1-L-ht and 1′-L-ht indicated that the framework had a strong affinity for binding H2 (Table and Figure ). At 77 K and 1.06 bar (800 Torr), a fully reversible uptake of 105.8 mL/g H2 for 1-L-ht but 66.7 cm3/g H2 for 1′-L-ht are apparent. As a further test, a second H2 adsorption isotherm was measured at 87 K, and the two data sets were used to determine the isosteric heat of H2 adsorption. The enthalpy of H2 adsorption for 1-L-ht and 1′-L-ht and was estimated from the sorption isotherms at 77 and 87 K using the virial equation to understand the affinity of 1-L-ht and 1′-L-ht toward H2 ( Figure S8–10). The isosteric heat of H2 adsorption for 1-L-ht and 1′-L-ht reach the values of 8.2 and 7.5 kJ/mol.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermal Stability

Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) and X-ray powder diffraction pattern (XRPD) measurements were carried out to examine the thermal stability of this nanoporous framework. The TGA curve of 1-L shows that the trapped solvent DMF molecules can be drastically removed at 250 °C with a weight loss of 35.4% (calculated 35.6%) ( Figure S2a). The hollow phase (1-L-ht) of 1-L was obtained after heated at 180 °C for 7 h under high vacuum (10-8 mbar), the powder X-ray diffraction pattern of 1-L-ht have appeared obvious change ( Figure S3c). It may be due to the laxity of 1-L after the removal of DMF guests. To attain a more complete evacuation and protect the structural integrality, DMF was exchanged with methanol by soaking crystals of 1-L in methanol for one week. As indicated by TGA and infrared spectroscopy, the methanol activated material 1'-L is DMF free ( Figures S2b and S4). Its TGA curve showed that methanol was released below 100 °C. Its hollow phase (1'-L-ht) was obtained after heated at 80 °C for 7 h under high vacuum.

Gas Sorption Properties

The permanent porosity of 1-L-ht was established by reversible gas sorption experiments using N2 and CO2 at 77 and 195 K, respectively, which all show a typical type I behavior characterized by a plateau reached at low relative pressure indicating the presence of permanent micropores in 1-L-ht (Figure  and Table ). The lower uptake of N2 (42 cm3/g) and higher uptake of CO2 (127 cm3/g) may be induced by the strong polar environment in the pores. N2 adsorption data gives a BET surface area of 136.9 m2/g and a Langmuir surface area of 180.4 m2/g. A single data point at relative pressure 0.295 gives a maxima pore volume of 0.063 cm3/g by the Horvath-Kawazoe equation. Comparatively, the maximum N2 uptakes at 1 bar for 1'-L-ht are 92.3 cm3/g (STP), giving a BET surface area of 224.7 m2/g and a Langmuir surface area of 298.5 m2/g, which are all much larger than that for 1-L-ht. A single data point at relative pressure 0.01 gives a maxima pore volume of 0.081 cm3/g by the Horvath-Kawazoe equation. The results demonstrate the importance of activation for porous materials.

The high-press sorption experiments of CO2 and CO were also measured at 298 K for 1-L-ht, which show distinct sorption behavior. The CO2 uptake by 1-L-ht at 40 bar can reach 84 cm3/g (3.75 mmol/g) and are not fully saturated, while the saturated uptake of CO is limited to 22 cm3/g (0.98 mmol/g) at 26 bar (Figure ). Interestingly, there is significant hysteresis for CO2 sorption whereas it is opposite for CO sorption. The significant hysteresis for 1-L-ht may be attributed to the dynamic feature of the host framework. The selective adsorption of CO2 over CO may be attributed to the sorbate-sorbent affinity between the CO2 molecules and the polar framework.

Low-pressure H2 adsorption isotherms collected for samples of 1-L-ht and 1'-L-ht indicated that the framework had a strong affinity for binding H2 (Table  and Figure ). At 77 K and 1.06 bar (800 Torr), a fully reversible uptake of 105.8 mL/g H2 for 1-L-ht but 66.7 cm3/g H2 for 1'-L-ht are apparent. As a further test, a second H2 adsorption isotherm was measured at 87 K, and the two data sets were used to determine the isosteric heat of H2 adsorption. The enthalpy of H2 adsorption for 1-L-ht and 1'-L-ht and was estimated from the sorption isotherms at 77 and 87 K using the virial equation to understand the affinity of 1-L-ht and 1'-L-ht toward H2 ( Figure S8-10). The isosteric heat of H2 adsorption for 1-L-ht and 1'-L-ht reach the values of 8.2 and 7.5 kJ/mol.

[gpt.ft]Table 1. Crystal Data and Structure Refinement for 1-L and 1-D

| chemical formula            | c<sub>22</sub>h<sub>14</sub>n<sub>2</sub>o<sub>14</sub>zn<sub>4</sub> | c<sub>22</sub>h<sub>14</sub>n<sub>2</sub>o<sub>14</sub>zn<sub>4</sub> |
| formula mass                | 791.83             | 791.83             |

| b (Å)                       | 14.332(3)          | 14.437(10)         |

cln_elements.content:
Adsorption Data and Isosteric Heat Data for <bold>1-L-ht</bold> and <bold>1́-L-ht</bold> compound BET CO2@273 K CO2@298 K Qst(CO2) S(CO2/N2)@273 K H2@77 K H2@87 K Qst(H2) 1-L-ht 136.9 55.5 37.1 32.1 185 105.8 79.8 8.2 1′-L-ht 224.7 43.7 30.3 28.6 17.5 66.7 50.7 7.5

Surface area, m2/g.

Adsorptive capability, mL/g.

Isosteric heat of adsorption at 1 bar, kJ/mol.

Selectivity of CO2 over N2, v/v.
(a) Coordination environment of Zn atom in 1-L. (b) The 3D porous framework viewed along the c axis.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Coordination environment of Zn atom in 1-L. (b) The 3D porous framework viewed along the c axis.

cln_elements.content: N2 and CO2 adsorption isotherms: (a) N2 at 77 K for 1-L-ht, (b) N2 at 77 K for 1′-L-ht, (c) CO2 at 195 K for 1-L-ht, and (d) the hysteresis loop of CO2 at 195 K for 1-L-ht.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  N2 and CO2 adsorption isotherms: (a) N2 at 77 K for 1-L-ht, (b) N2 at 77 K for 1'-L-ht, (c) CO2 at 195 K for 1-L-ht, and (d) the hysteresis loop of CO2 at 195 K for 1-L-ht.

cln_elements.content: N2 and CO2 adsorption isotherms: (a) CO2 at 273 K for 1-L-ht, (b) CO2 at 298 K for 1-L-ht, (c) CO2 at 273 K for 1′-L-ht, (d) CO2 at 298 K for 1′-L-ht, (e) N2 at 273 K for 1-L-ht and (f) N2 at 273 K for 1′-L-ht.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  N2 and CO2 adsorption isotherms: (a) CO2 at 273 K for 1-L-ht, (b) CO2 at 298 K for 1-L-ht, (c) CO2 at 273 K for 1'-L-ht, (d) CO2 at 298 K for 1'-L-ht, (e) N2 at 273 K for 1-L-ht and (f) N2 at 273 K for 1'-L-ht.

cln_elements.content: High-pressure adsorption isotherms of CO2 and CO at 298 K for 1-L-ht.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  High-pressure adsorption isotherms of CO2 and CO at 298 K for 1-L-ht.

cln_elements.content: H2 adsorption isotherms: (a) H2 at 77 K for 1-L-ht, (b) H2 at 87 K for 1-L-ht, (c) H2 at 77 K for 1′-L-ht, (d) H2 at 87 K for 1′-L-ht.
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  H2 adsorption isotherms: (a) H2 at 77 K for 1-L-ht, (b) H2 at 87 K for 1-L-ht, (c) H2 at 77 K for 1'-L-ht, (d) H2 at 87 K for 1'-L-ht.

cln_elements.content: H2 adsorption isotherm for 1-L-ht recorded at 77 K, and the red solid line is the fitting of the H2 adsorption isotherm of 1-L-ht using Langmuir–Freundlich equation.

metadata.title: Serine-Based Homochiral Nanoporous Frameworks for Selective CO2 Uptake
